title: Timeline of the Troubles
text:
The <a href="Troubles">Troubles</a> were a period of conflict in <a href="Northern%20Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> involving <a href="Irish%20republicanism">republican</a> and <a href="Ulster%20loyalism">loyalist</a> <a href="paramilitary">paramilitaries</a>, the <a href="Law%20enforcement%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">British security forces</a>, and civil rights groups. They are usually dated from the late 1960s through to the <a href="Good%20Friday%20Agreement">Good Friday Agreement</a> of 1998. However, sporadic violence continued after this point. Those that continued violence past this point are referred to as "<a href="dissident%20republican">dissident republican</a>s and loyalists". By 1998 the Troubles had claimed roughly 3500 lives.
Prior to 1960.
Since <a href="Partition%20of%20Ireland">partition</a>, the <a href="Irish%20Republican%20Army%20%281922%E2%80%9369%29">IRA</a> had started a number of military operations in <a href="Northern%20Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> designed at bringing about their goal of a <a href="United%20Ireland">United Ireland</a>. The intensity of this activity increased towards the end of 1941, where the IRA decided to step up its <a href="Northern%20Campaign%20%28Irish%20Republican%20Army%29">campaign of attacks in Northern Ireland</a>. In response to this activity the Unionist authorities under <a href="J.%20M.%20Andrews">John Miller Andrews</a> introduced internment and using provisions of the <a href="Emergency%20Powers%20Act%20%28Northern%20Ireland%29%201926">Emergency Powers Act</a>, instituted increasingly restrictive policies in Northern Ireland. This pattern of paramilitary violence, followed by increasingly restrictive measures on the behalf of the authorities came to define the run-up to the Troubles.
1960–1969.
Since 1964, <a href="Northern%20Ireland%20civil-rights%20movement%20%281960s%29">civil rights activists</a> had been protesting against the discrimination against <a href="Irish%20Catholic">Catholics</a> and <a href="Irish%20nationalism">Irish nationalists</a> by the <a href="Ulster%20Protestant">Ulster Protestant</a> and <a href="Unionism%20in%20Ireland">unionist</a> <a href="government%20of%20Northern%20Ireland">government of Northern Ireland</a>. The civil rights movement called for: '<a href="one%20man%2C%20one%20vote">one man, one vote</a>'; the end to <a href="Gerrymandering">gerrymandered</a> electoral boundaries; the end to discrimination in employment and in the allocation of public housing; repeal of the <a href="Civil%20Authorities%20%28Special%20Powers%29%20Act%20%28Northern%20Ireland%29%201922">Special Powers Act</a>; and the disbanding of the <a href="Ulster%20Special%20Constabulary">Ulster Special Constabulary</a>.
